did.unittitle: Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina records span the years 1750 to 2014 and document the origins and daily operations of the organization, which preserves and presents the history of the Jewish people of North Carolina through public programming, exhibits, and other projects. The collection includes documents and digital material related to the planning, funding, and carrying out of various exhibits, events and projects, especially the multimedia program "Down Home: Jewish Life in North Carolina." Also present are primary and secondary research materials collected by JHFNC historian Leonard Rogoff related to the history and culture of Jews in North Carolina and southern Jewish identity. Types of materials in the collection include financial statements, meeting minutes, correspondence, reports, typescripts, newsletters, marketing materials, photographs, research notes, and audiovisual material. Digital materials include photographs, administrative and promotional materials, and project design materials.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by: Mary Samouelian, Mary Mellon, Matthew Farrell, and Oisin Harrington, June 2015.
Accessions described in this finding aid: 2014-0125, 2014-0126, 2014-0138

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina Records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in June, 2014.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina Records, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials may require production of listening or viewing copies before use.

Electronic records in this collection have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library Reading Room. To request access, please contact Research Services before coming to use these records.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48-hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina (JHFNC) is an independent organization dedicated to preserving and presenting the history of the Jewish people of North Carolina. Through public programming and exhibits, the JHFNC aspires to educate and showcase the richness of Jewish Life as well as promote a familiarity with the culture and lifestyle of Jews to the general public.

eventgrp.event: The organization begins as the Efraim and Marian Rosenzweig Judaica and Hebraica Exhibit at the Judea Reform Congregation, with the original Rosenzweig collection of art, artifacts, and rare books relating to Jewish Family life.
The Rosenzweig Museum is established, with the goal of displaying a collection of Judaica bequeathed to Durham's Judea Reform Congregation.

The museum is incorporated as an independent non-profit organization and renamed The Rosenzweig Museum of the Jewish Family (also known as The Museum of the Jewish Family and Rosenzweig Gallery), with Lenora Ucko as Director.
The organization's name is changed to the Rosenzweig Museum and Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina.
The Rosenzweig Museum and the Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina divide into two entities.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina (JHFNC) records span the years 1750 to 2014 and document the origins and daily operations of the organization. The collection includes documents and digital material related to the planning, funding, and carrying out of various exhibits, events and projects, especially the multimedia program "Down Home: Jewish Life in North Carolina." Also present are primary and secondary research materials collected by JHFNC historian Leonard Rogoff related to the history and culture of Jews in North Carolina and southern Jewish identity.

Types of materials in the collection include financial statements, meeting minutes, correspondence, reports, typescripts, newsletters, marketing materials, photographs, research notes, and audiovisual material. Digital materials include photographs, administrative and promotional materials, and project design materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into four series: Administrative records, Exhibits, events and projects, Subject files, and Audiovisual.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina collection of Jewish historical materials, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series document the daily operations of the JHFNC and its predecessor organizations, beginning with the Efraim and Marian Rosenzweig Judaica and Hebraica Exhibit at the Judea Reform Congregation. The series also contains materials related to the building of the foundation's archival collections and documents the ultimate destination of archival materials and museum artifacts after the 2003 separation of the JHFNC and Rosenzweig Museum.

Types of material in the series include financial statements, board and committee meeting agendas and minutes, correspondence, reports, bylaws, articles of incorporation, newsletters, artifact appraisals, accession worksheets, loan and donor agreements, photographs of objects, and background research on specific artifacts. Digital materials in the series include computer and email backups, donor and contact databases, marketing and promotional materials, and digital photographs and documents related to museum accessions.

Throughout the series, titles of folders related to specific Rosenzweig/JHFNC accessions reflect the 6-digit accession numbering system established by the Rosenzweig Gallery, with the first two digits representing the year the artifact or archival material was accessioned.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The folders are arranged chronologically and alphabetically thereafter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These digital files were created as backups of administrative material related to the JFHNC, the Rosenzweig Gallery, and various JHFNC projects. Materials include documents and images used for annual appeals ("Case for support"), publicity mailings and posters, letterhead and business cards, donation and pledge acknowledgement letters, and information about the JHFNC board. Files related to the Down Home project include images, design files, internal memos, budgets, project schedules and updates, and information for local campaigns in Greensboro, Wilmington, Durham/Chapel Hill, and Charlotte.

Types of material include strategy and planning documents, design files, business cards, and newsletters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the several exhibits, events, and projects that the Rosenzweig Gallery and JHFNC initiated, funded, and organized in Durham, NC, and elsewhere. Major projects and exhibits represented include "What We Brought with Us," "Migrations," Rosenzweig Gallery art exhibits and annual juried art shows, "A History of Temple Emanu-El, Weldon, NC," and "Down Home."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this series are arranged into two subseries: Down Home and Other exhibits, events and projects.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Oral history recordings and transcripts related to Down Home, Migrations, and other projects are located in the Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina Oral History Collection. Other audiovisual material related to Rosenzweig/JHFNC projects is located in the Audiovisual Series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this subseries document the multimedia program "Down Home: Jewish Life in North Carolina" from its inception to its execution. The materials related to the exhibit include correspondence, concept plans, various design drafts and revisions, meeting notes, exhibit plans, outlines, docent notes, artifacts lists, and scripts and curricula associated with the exhibit. Materials related to the Down Home film and book includes contracts, drafts and revisions, correspondence, talks and events, and promotional materials. The subseries also contains materials related to the JHFNC's fundraising and marketing efforts for the Down Home project, including events, mailing campaigns, prospectuses, and various grant applications.

Digital materials in this series consist of digitized photographs, historical documents, and design files used in the research for Down Home and the creation of the exhibit, book, documentary film, promotional materials, and related products. Also included are digital photographs of events related to Down Home.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this subseries are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These digital files include photographs of and historical documents related to the various municipalities, businesses, temples, synagogues, community centers, families, and individuals profiled in Down Home. Many of the images were used previously in the Migrations exhibit, as is reflected by folder names and creation dates within the file directories. Some of the images originated from the special collections and archives of other institutions, usually indicated by disc label or folder names.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this subseries describe various Rosenzweig/JHFNC exhibits and events at the Rosenzweig Gallery and throughout North Carolina including the exhibits "Migrations," "The Running Stag," and "What We Brought With Us: Mementos of the Flight From Europe 1933 to 1950" (also known as the Ucko Exhibit); and the annual art shows at the Rosenzweig Gallery. It also contains materials related to the monograph "An Extended Family: A History of Temple Emanu-El, Weldon, North Carolina" (also known as the Weldon project).

The series contains postcards, typescripts, correspondence related to grant funding efforts, promotional material, photographs of exhibit objects and events, and background research materials. Digital materials in the subseries include digital photographs of Rosenzweig Gallery art show submissions, exhibits, and events, and digitized photographs and historical documents used for the Migrations exhibit and Weldon project.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The folders in this subseries are arranged loosely alphabetically by exhibit/event/project and chronologically thereafter.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Digital material related to Migrations can also be found in the Down Home subseries, as many digital photographs originating with the Migrations project were copied and reused for the Down Home project. Historical records related to Temple Emanu-El in Weldon, NC are located in the North Carolina Temple and Synagogue Historical Collection.

scopecontent.p: These digital files include photographs and scanned images related to Weldon, as well as Whitakers and other nearby towns. Locations represented include Temple Emanu-El and Bloom Store. A scan of a Weldon Sabbath School program (1926), and 1 audio file (.aif format) related to Harry Kittner are also present.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Subject files series contains materials collected by JHFNC historian Leonard Rogoff that are primarily related to his research for various JHFNC projects and personal interests including "Down Home," "Migrations," Southern Jewish identity, North Carolina synagogues, temples, and congregations, and the history of the Durham-Chapel Hill Jewish community.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this series are arranged into two subseries: North Carolina municipalities and Topical subject files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The primary focuses of the materials in this subseries are on the Jewish families and communities in various North Carolina cities, towns, and villages. The contents include clippings, articles, obituaries, newsletters, and individual, family, and synagogue and temple histories. Also included are primary manuscript materials, transcripts from oral histories, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The folders in this subseries are arranged loosely in alphabetical order, reflecting the original order of the materials.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Digital photographs and other files related to North Carolina municipalities are located in the Exhibits, Events, and Projects series and are arranged by the project they were associated with.

did.unittitle: Charlotte - CAJE (Carolina Agency for Jewish Education)

Community Midrasha [Jewish Federation of Durham/Chapel Hill]
Kitty Hawk - Jewish Community Outer Banks
New Bern - Temple Chester B'nai Sholem

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The topics in this subseries vary widely but primarily focus on North Carolina and southern Jewish history from the early 1800s to the present. The contents include clippings, articles, newsletters, photocopied research papers and manuscript materials; excerpts from books, family genealogies and histories, and other printed materials; photographs; and some of Rogoff's research-related correspondence, handwritten notes, bibliographies, outlines, and typed speeches on various topics.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The folders in this subseries are arranged loosely alphabetically, reflecting the original order of the materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in the Audiovisual series consist of raw and edited video recordings related to the documentary film "Down Home: Jewish life in North Carolina" and other JHFNC/Rosenzweig Museum projects and exhibits, and various sound and video recordings related to Jewish history and culture, including documentary films, television programs, and religious services.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this series are arranged into the following subseries: Down Home video recordings, Documentaries and television programs, and Other audiovisual material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The video recordings in this subseries include raw and edited footage of individuals, groups, and locations featured in the documentary film "Down Home: Jewish life in North Carolina," which was produced by Video Dialog, Inc. Also included are recordings from other documentary projects that were produced by Video Dialog or obtained by the JHFNC for use in "Down Home." Note that addiitional interviews created for "Down Home" are located in the Jewish Heritage Foundation of North Carolina Oral History Collection also at the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The video recordings in this subseries include various documentaries and television programs related to Jews in the American South as well as other aspects of Jewish history and culture. Among the recordings are features on Rosenzweig Gallery exhibits and Duke University professor and JHFNC president Dr. Eric Meyers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this subseries are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The video and sound recordings in this series are mainly unpublished recordings of religious services and other programming at North Carolina Jewish congregations. The series includes sound recordings of Rabbi Efraim Rosenzweig (Judea Reform Congregation), and other recordings related to Rosenzweig/JHFNC events and exhibits. Other materials in the subseries include home recordings acquired by the JHFNC from North Carolina Jewish families, including the Farber family of Weldon, NC, the Leder family of Wilson, NC, and the Shrago and Lacob families of Goldsboro and Fayetteville, NC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this subseries are arranged chronologically.
